statement:
Let $A$ be a set of natural numbers. Let $R_n(A)$ be the number of ways
to represent $n$ as a sum of two elements in $A$, that is,
$$R_n(A)=\sum_{\substack{a_i+a_j=n\\a_i,a_j \in A}} 1.$$

Erdős-Fuchs theorem
[@cite:erdos_fuchs_lowbnd; @cite:halberstam_sequences] states that if
$c>0$, then $$\label{erdfcheq}
\sum_{n \leq N} R_n(A)=c N + o\left(N^{\frac{1}{4}}\log^{-\frac{1}{2}}N\right)$$
cannot hold.

On the other hand, Ruzsa [@cite:ruzsa_upperdfch] constructed a set for
which
$$\sum_{n \leq N} R_n(A)=c N + O\left(N^{\frac{1}{4}}\log N\right).$$

Montgomery and Vaughan [@cite:montgomery_vaughan_fch] improved on the
original Erdős-Fuchs theorem by showing that for every $c>0$
$$\max_{N\leq M}\left\lvert \sum_{n \leq N} R_n(A)-c n\right\rvert=
\Omega\left(M^{\frac{1}{4}}\log^{-\frac{1}{4}}M\right)$$ holds. In
[@cite:montgomery_vaughan_fch] a result of Jurkat is cited which
appeared in the Ph. D. thesis of Hayashi [@cite:hayashi_fch] which
improves $N^{\frac{1}{4}}\log^{-\frac{1}{2}}N$ in to $N^{\frac{1}{4}}$.
